key_points: Qiamuddin Safi, an East Bay man who recently escaped Afghanistan, has family members who were victims in the Kabul airport attack.
Safi's cousin, a longtime interpreter for the U.S. Army, was killed in one of the deadly blasts at Abbey Gate.
Safi's brother and another cousin are in the ICU, while two other cousins are hospitalized.
Safi highlighted the danger his family faced despite having Special Immigration Visas (SIV).
The attack adds to the heartache and fear within the Afghan community in the United States.
Community leaders and organizations are rallying to support Afghan refugees and bring attention to human rights violations in Afghanistan.
Safi's family worked for the U.S. government, making them Taliban targets.
Despite reaching out to Bay Area lawmakers for help with his family's SIV application, Safi's pleas were not answered.
The tragic events amplify the confusion and grief among those trying to help their families escape Afghanistan.
Safi's cousin, killed in the attack, left behind two young children and was expecting another.
spokespersons: Sara Fain (attorney, Immigration Institute of the Bay Area)
